It seems to me the entire debate stems down to one issue that is heavily moral to the point no side will ever concede the point:
 
 "Is the fetus a human being?"
 
 This is not an obvious question. From the moment of conception, is it a human? Is it a human when it is composed of 4 cells? 16 cells? Has appendages? Has a heartbeat? Has a nervouse system? Hours before it's born?
 
 
 Many would phrase this in terms of the baby having a soul, but we live in secular times and the most common arguement I hear is potential life. An analogy would be, as far as I can tell, that it's just as morally reprehensible to cut down a tree as to destroy a seed. You can argue that it's reprehensible comparing human life with tree life but the analogy is there. 
 
 I see the fetus as a human when it has a central nervous system. In this sense, I have no objections to 1st trimester abortions but become concerned any later than this.
 
 The irony is that we all fall somewhere on the line of pregnancy from no abortions at all to minutes before birth. We aren't about to move from our place either. The real batlle of this issue lies with the next generation.

. . . .The irony is that we all fall somewhere on the line of pregnancy from no abortions at all to minutes before birth. . . .

 You know, this little phrase, "minutes before birth," keeps popping up in reference to abortion.
 
 Could someone please explain to me the point of having an abortion "minutes before birth"? What is the point?
 
 How many, if any, of this sort of abortion is performed?
 
 Could I get a really honest answer to that? Please, no lies.
 
 How many?
 
 Can anyone tell me?

I think he(in the general non-sex sense of the word) is referring to the so called "partial birth abortion"
 
 This is not exactly an unbiased site but it gives you an idea of some of the reasons...they kinda run the same route as abortions in the late 1st trimester to early 2nd (as in same reasons). Many are depression or something will be wrong with the baby.
 http://www.nrlc.org/abortion/pba/pbafact10.html
 
 Here is another link to some reasons but they don't actually state any reasons that have actually been done like the above link.
 http://www.abortionaccess.org/AAP/publica_resources/commentaries/latest.htm
 
 Here is a link from BBC News that takes a little bit about it
 
 Why are they carried out?
 
 Some members of the pro-choice lobby and a number of doctors argue that partial-birth abortion is a necessary procedure, usually carried out when the life or health of the mother is at risk, or the foetus is severely disabled.
 
 However, opponents say that in many cases the procedure is carried out when it is not medically necessary to save the life of the mother.
 
 They also argue that it sometimes used for what they define as social reasons - for instance, when the mother is suffering from depression. 
http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3246407.stm
 
 Another biased reasons site
 http://www.pregnantpause.org/abort/whypb.htm
 
 
 
 About 2,200 are done a year give or take
 http://www.abortionaccess.org/partial-birthabortion.htm#Q:%20How%20many%20women%20get%20D&X%20abortions%20each%20year
 
 I am sure you know it isn't easy to get unbiased information...either you are for abortion or not so "neutral" sites aren't going to be easy to come by.
 
 The 2,200 number is fairly solid though.
You're evading my question, Steeeve. Where are the abortions that occur "minutes before birth"?

You're evading my question, Steeeve. Where are the abortions that occur "minutes before birth"?

 
 I thought I just said that. I wasn't evading anything.
 
 
I think he(in the general non-sex sense of the word) is referring to the so called "partial birth abortion"

 
 If he meant natural birth then I don't know.

. . . .The irony is that we all fall somewhere on the line of pregnancy from no abortions at all to minutes before birth. . . .
You are trying to project your own bias by imputing that chaoticgnome has stated something that I do not believe he said.

You are trying to project your own bias by imputing that chaoticgnome has stated something that I do not believe he said.
 What is your problem? Seriously, I am trying to make an effort in good faith to answer your question and you just insult me. I honestly thought he was referring paritial birth abortion because that is the only procedure that could be seen as "minutes before birth". If he wasn't referring to this then I have no idea. Try showing some respect every now and then.

Why is the so-called "partial birth" abortion the only explanation for having an abortion "minutes before birth"?
 
 That's not my understanding of the phrase at all.

Why is the so-called "partial birth" abortion the only explanation for having an abortion "minutes before birth"?
 
 That's not my understanding of the phrase at all.

 
 Its the only one I could think of....wow, you need to chill out sometimes, I was just trying to help you out.
Perhaps you ought to think a bit more?

"Is the fetus a human being?"

 
 It is not so much the "human" part as it is the "being" part. Or for me, the "person" part.
 
 We have human sperm, human ova, human zygotes, human fetus, etc as opposed to cat sperm, etc.
 
 The real question is, when is it a person? When is it a life of it's own?
 
 I don't have an answer for that. That is what I think each person must decide on their own.

It is not so much the "human" part as it is the "being" part. Or for me, the "person" part.
 
 We have human sperm, human ova, human zygotes, human fetus, etc as opposed to cat sperm, etc.
 
 The real question is, when is it a person? When is it a life of it's own?
 
 I don't have an answer for that. That is what I think each person must decide on their own.

 I am a bit confused by this post. It seems to me that you either know what a person is or you don't. You say you don't know whether a fetus is a person or not. But, you say that each person should decide the answer to this question on their own. So on one hand, you don't seem to know whether the fetus is a person or not, while on the other you do seem to know that the mother of the fetus is a person.
 
 So, why couldn't you just explain what it is that makes the mother a person, and then see if the fetus fits within that criteria? In other words, you have a prototype for what a person is, since you claim that each person should decide the question of the status of the fetus. Therefore, you should be able to examine whether or not the fetus fits that prototype.

"Is the fetus a human being?"

 For me, the term "human being" is synonymous with "person". As for the definition of person, I would think that, at a minimum, it would need to include a mental existence, not just a physical one.

Simone, you obviously need to take a chill pill. Steeeeve was only trying to help you and when you got an answer you didn't like, you went all anal on him. When chaoticgnome said:
 
 
 The irony is that we all fall somewhere on the line of pregnancy from no abortions at all to minutes before birth. 
 
 
 I believe he was talking about the two ends of the spectrum of opinions on abortion. With that in mind, "minutes before birth" would refer to those people in the far corner who think that abortions should be allowed even minutes before birth. Obviously, that idea is a little too radical for most people and from my knowledge, it's illegal right now anyway.
 
 Of course, this is just my interpretation, if you don't like it, then suck it up and wait for chaoticgnome to come back.

Beowulf, your interpretation of chaoticgnome's statement is quite different from that of Steeeve and it sound more, to me, like what chaoticgnome intended in his original statement.
 
 I merely took issue with Steeeve's characterization of abortion "minutes before birth" as the so-called "partial birth" abortion.
 
 But, on the other hand, what is the point of obtaining an abortion "minutes before birth" unless there are serious health issues to consider.
 
 It sounds really stupid to get an abortion "minutes before birth." I don't even understand why someone would say such a stupid thing.

I can't quite figure out why you have been so disagreeable in this discussion. You asked some questions, but when someone tried to answer them, you just lashed out with insulting commentary. Was your question a set-up so that you could lash out at anyone trying to answer it?
 
 
I merely took issue with Steeeve's characterization of abortion "minutes before birth" as the so-called "partial birth" abortion.

 Indeed you did. Yet, I think it is blatantly obvious that a partial birth abortion fits the criteria of an abortion minutes before birth.
 
 
But, on the other hand, what is the point of obtaining an abortion "minutes before birth" unless there are serious health issues to consider.

 In the overall question, it doesn't really matter what the point would be. The overall question is what does one's philosophical system logically allow. And for some on this forum, their philosophical system would logically allow one to obtain an abortion minutes before birth with no moral repercussions.
 
 
It sounds really stupid to get an abortion "minutes before birth." I don't even understand why someone would say such a stupid thing.

 Anyone using autonomy as a moral justification for abortion can conceivably be led to the logical conclusion that one may obtain an abortion minutes before birth no matter how stupid you think they would be. The fact that you think something is stupid does not therefore mean that 1) it doesn't actually occur and/or 2) that some people may think it permissable.

Let me replay the dialogue:
 Forgive me for failing to understand why "abortion minutes before birth" immediately translates to the so-called "partial birth" abortion. It just doesn't make any sense.

 What else could it be? I think that's the route steeeve took.
 
 
Why, precisely?

 Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003
 
 Partial Birth Abortion as defined in the bill above is:
 
`(1) the term `partial -birth abortion' means an abortion in which the person performing the abortion--
 `(A) deliberately and intentionally vaginally delivers a living fetus until, in the case of a head-first presentation, the entire fetal head is outside the body of the mother, or, in the case of breech presentation, any part of the fetal trunk past the navel is outside the body of the mother, for the purpose of performing an overt act that the person knows will kill the partially delivered living fetus; and
 `(B) performs the overt act, other than completion of delivery, that kills the partially delivered living fetus;

 
 So, the fetus is partially outside the body of the mother, and then is killed. If birth is defined as the fetus being fully outside the body of the mother, then the above procedure effectively kills the fetus seconds before birth. Granted this is not minutes before birth, I think the general idea is shown.
 
 
Philosophical systems play a large role in one's decision to have an abortion? Why do so many Roman Catholic women--women who are rabidly opposed to the idea of other women exercising their right to choose an abortion--have abortions themselves? What happened to their "philosophical systems"?

 Evidence?
 
 
I'm trying to understand what the sentence "Anyone using autonomy as a moral justification for abortion can conceivably be led to the logical conclusion that one may obtain an abortion minutes before birth no matter how stupid you think they would be" means. Could you explain? Please?

 What I meant is that a logical conclusion of some people's system would be the permissable aborting of a fetus minutes before birth. The fact that you think that aborting a fetus minutes before birth is stupid does not change that.

Simone when you go do a Google on the phrase, " minutes before birth" (in reference to abortions) it gives you partial birth abortion sites. 
 
 Chaoticgnome is the only one who can truly clarify what the phrase meant when posted.

I am a bit confused by this post. It seems to me that you either know what a person is or you don't. You say you don't know whether a fetus is a person or not. But, you say that each person should decide the answer to this question on their own. So on one hand, you don't seem to know whether the fetus is a person or not, while on the other you do seem to know that the mother of the fetus is a person.
 
 So, why couldn't you just explain what it is that makes the mother a person, and then see if the fetus fits within that criteria? In other words, you have a prototype for what a person is, since you claim that each person should decide the question of the status of the fetus. Therefore, you should be able to examine whether or not the fetus fits that prototype.

 
 I have no problem with the mother as person, she has been born and is a living, thinking, active "person."
 
 A just born baby is a person, based on the Constitution (14th Amendment, all persons born, etc).
 
 But before that? I don't know, I don't have to decide as I will not be pregnant in the future. But in the "olden days" quickening was probably the determining factor. That is when most women knew for sure that they were pregnant with no doubt.
 
 I can't judge women who decide their fetus is not a person at the time of abortion. I do know that first trimester is a "no-brainer" for me as far as the legality for abortion. Second trimester is probably okay and the third is not in my view. However, the third trimester should not be a deterent if the health of the mother is at issue. She's most important or the rest of the family will not survive.

My understanding of the laws controlling abortion is that the more advanced the pregnancy the more difficult it is to obtain an abortion. Second trimester abortions are difficult to obtain. It is almost impossible to obtain a third trimester abortion save for the most stringent reasons.

I can't judge women who decide their fetus is not a person at the time of abortion. I do know that first trimester is a "no-brainer" for me as far as the legality for abortion. Second trimester is probably okay and the third is not in my view. However, the third trimester should not be a deterent if the health of the mother is at issue. She's most important or the rest of the family will not survive.
 I know I have told you this before but a trimester has no science meaning in it at all. It is simply just a term to say "3 months". I'm not sure how a man-made time split can be used to determine who is an isnt' a person...but maybe you can explain this.
 
 
I merely took issue with Steeeve's characterization of abortion "minutes before birth" as the so-called "partial birth" abortion.
 Perhaps you could just say "Thanks for helping but I don't think that is what it means" instead of flaming.
In the first 3 months of each of my pregnancies I heard a heartbeat. It was enough to let me know my life was going to change.

Basic pregnancy facts:
 
 The duration of a normal pregnancy is roughly nine months--and it can be a rough nine months for the woman involved.
 
 For purposes of determining the maturity and viability of a ferilized egg, zygote, embryo, fetus, etc., the roughly nine-month pregnancy is divided into three trimesters. The first trimester is the first three months of a pregnancy. It follows, therefore, that the second trimester is the next three months and the third trimester is the very last three months.
 
 Spontaneous abortions may occur within any trimester of pregnancy but usually if a pregnancy passes through the first trimester the likely incidence of a spontaneous abortion decreases.
 
 Now, that is very, very basic and that should not be very hard to assimiliate.

But a trimester still has no science significiance of any kind...it is literally just a way to divide a pregnancy up into 3 periods...just like colleges normally divide their years into semesters...etc.

No scientific or medical significance, Steeeeve?
 
 Are you a medical doctor or a scientist that you can make that statement? What is your particular expertise in this matter?
